text: The Goethals Bridge is a cantilever bridge that connects Elizabeth, New Jersey and Staten Island, New York. It was designed by John Alexander Low Waddell, who also designed the Outerbridge Crossing. It was built by the Port of New York Authority (now the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey).Richman, Steven M. (2005). The Bridges of New Jersey: Portraits of Garden State Crossings. New Brunswick: Rutgers University Press. pp. 103â€“104. . It opened on June 29, 1928, the same day that the Outerbridge Crossing opened. It was named after George Washington Goethals, who was the first consulting engineer of the Port Authority. The bridge of one of three bridges that connect Staten Island with New Jersey. The other bridges are the Outerbridge Crossing and the Bayonne Bridge in Bayonne, New Jersey. The bridge was replaced in 2018 with a pair of cable-stayed bridges. The old bridge was demolished soon after. The new bridge has pedestrian and bicycle access, which the old one didn't have. ==References== ==Other websites== Category:Bridges in New York City Category:Cantilever bridges Category:Staten Island Category:1928 establishments in the United States Category:1920s establishments in New York (state) Category:2017 disestablishments in the United States Category:2010s disestablishments in New York (state) Category:2017 establishments in the United States Category:2010s establishments in New York (state)
title: Goethals Bridge
